articles.headline: As U.S. Retailers Retreat, a Japanese Chain Sees an Opening
articles.snippet: The Japanese basics brand Uniqlo, betting on a comeback for the American consumer, is taking advantage of recession-lowered rents to expand in the United States.
articles.abstract: The Japanese basics brand Uniqlo, betting on a comeback for the American consumer, is taking advantage of recession-lowered rents to expand in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: Many American retailers are cutting back at shopping malls. Chains like Gap Inc., Abercrombie & Fitch, Coldwater Creek and Talbot’s say they have too many stores at too many malls. Hundreds of stores are on the chopping block.

articles.headline: Venture Capital Partner Claims Sexual Harassment
articles.snippet: Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, the blue-chip Silicon Valley venture capital firm known for its early investments in Google, is being sued by one of its investment partners who says she faced sexual harassment at the firm.
articles.abstract: Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, the blue-chip Silicon Valley venture capital firm known for its early investments in Google, is being sued by one of its investment partners who says she faced sexual harassment at the firm.
articles.lead_paragraph: 9:35 p.m. | Updated  A partner at Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, the blue-chip Silicon Valley venture capital firm that was an early investor in Google and Amazon, is suing the firm, claiming that she faced sexual harassment and discrimination there over a six-year period.

articles.headline: Prized Logo Is Returned to Ford
articles.snippet: The company’s blue oval and other assets pledged as collateral for a $23.5 billion loan package were formally returned after a ratings upgrade on Tuesday.
articles.abstract: The company’s blue oval and other assets pledged as collateral for a $23.5 billion loan package were formally returned after a ratings upgrade on Tuesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The blue oval is back home.

articles.headline: The Modest Worth of Big Banks
articles.snippet: Measuring what huge financial institutions do is difficult, but their being oversize seems to add little to society.
articles.abstract: Measuring what huge financial institutions do is difficult, but their being oversize seems to add little to society.
articles.lead_paragraph: What can we afford to do about the financial industry?

articles.headline: For Native American Women, Scourge of Rape, Rare Justice
articles.snippet: The assault rate on tribal lands is higher than the national average, and reservation residents who report being attacked often confront gaps in medical and legal help.
articles.abstract: The assault rate on tribal lands is higher than the national average, and reservation residents who report being attacked often confront gaps in medical and legal help.
articles.lead_paragraph: EMMONAK, Alaska — She was 19, a young Alaska Native woman in this icebound fishing village of 800 in the Yukon River delta, when an intruder broke into her home and raped her. The man left. Shaking, the woman called the tribal police, a force of three. It was late at night. No one answered. She left a message on the department’s voice mail system. Her call was never returned. She was left to recover on her own.

articles.headline: Google Privacy Inquiries Get Little Cooperation
articles.snippet: All sorts of private Internet communications were casually scooped up as Google Street View cars photographed the world’s streets.
articles.abstract: All sorts of private Internet communications were casually scooped up as Google Street View cars photographed the world’s streets.
articles.lead_paragraph: Secrets spilled across the computer screen.
articles.byline: By David Streitfeld and Kevin J. O'Brien

articles.headline: After Paul Falters, Backers Push Agenda in Party and Other Races
articles.snippet: With Ron Paul having lost the nomination, his dedicated supporters are swarming lightly guarded Republican redoubts in an attempt to infiltrate the top echelons of the party.
articles.abstract: With Ron Paul having lost the nomination, his dedicated supporters are swarming lightly guarded Republican redoubts in an attempt to infiltrate the top echelons of the party.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Armed with an inherited fortune and a devotion to Ron Paul, John Ramsey, a 21-year-old college student from Nacogdoches, Tex., plunged into a little-watched Republican House primary in Northern Kentucky this spring to promote his version of freedom.

articles.headline: Leader of ’76 Insurgency Is Now a Target of One
articles.snippet: Senator Orrin G. Hatch, who led a one-man conservative uprising in Utah in 1976, is the latest Republican veteran hoping to fend off a primary challenger.
articles.abstract: Senator Orrin G. Hatch, who led a one-man conservative uprising in Utah in 1976, is the latest Republican veteran hoping to fend off a primary challenger.
articles.lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY — A conservative firebrand identifying himself as a nonpolitician denounces the economic and moral decay of a liberal agenda run amok in Washington, and urges voters to boot out a crusty incumbent who has fallen in love with his own reflection. Sounds like Tea Party 101, right?

articles.headline: Egyptians Vote in First Free Election for President
articles.snippet: Voters in Egypt hoped to seize the promise of a popular uprising that defined the Arab spring in an election that could end 15 chaotic months of military rule.
articles.abstract: Voters in Egypt hoped to seize the promise of a popular uprising that defined the Arab spring in an election that could end 15 chaotic months of military rule.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egyptians went to the polls on Wednesday to choose their first freely elected president, hoping to recapture the promise of a popular uprising that defined the Arab Spring, end 15 chaotic months of military rule and perhaps shape the character of political Islam across the region.
